    • identifySequenceRecursive

      private List<String> identifySequenceRecursive(List<String> result, List<String> input, Integer zeroes)
      Recursively identifies and builds a sequence of strings from an input list based on the presence of zeroes and their length. Consists of 2 terminal conditions
      1. If the zeroes == 0. The remaining character (if any) is part of the sequence only if it's length is less than the previously added character.
      2. If the input does not contain a "0". The remaining character (if any) is part of the sequence only if it's length is less than the previously added character.
      Parameters:
      result - The list to which matching strings will be added. It is updated in place.
      input - The list of strings to be processed.
      zeroes - The number of zeroes to be searched for in the strings. It decrements with each recursive call.
      Returns:
      The updated result list containing the strings that meet the specified conditions.

    • generateDivideAmbiguities

      private List<String> generateDivideAmbiguities(String number)
      This method takes as input a number and finds all ambiguities that could be divided from that number. For example 487 can be interpreted as [400 80 7, 480 7, 400 87, 487]. We call this 'divide ambiguities'. The process to calculate the 'divide ambiguities' is the following:
      • Reverse the input number (487-->784)
      • Store the first digit of the reversed number in divideAmbiguities List (example: 7)
      • For each digit in the reversed number repeat:
        • Create an incomingAmbiguities list that consists of 2 elements:
          • [digit] (example: 8)
          • [digit][i times 0], where i is the index of the digit in the reversed number (example: 80)
        • Combine divideAmbiguities and incomingAmbiguities to calculate the new list of divideAmbiguities. (example 807, 87)
      Parameters:
      number - The input number to find the 'divide ambiguities' for.
      Returns:
      a List that contains all the 'divide ambiguities' for the input number.

    • combineDivideAmbiguities

      private void combineDivideAmbiguities(List<String> list1, List<String> list2)
      Combines elements from two lists into a single list and updates the first list with the combined results.

      This method takes two lists of strings, list1 and list2. It creates a new list where each element of list1 is combined with each element of list2 in a specific manner. Specifically, each element in list1 is prefixed by the first element of list2 followed by a space, each element in list1 is prefixed by the second element of list2. The original list1 is then replaced with this newly created combined list.

      Parameters:
      list1 - The first list to be updated with the combined results. This list is cleared and replaced with the new combined list.
      list2 - The second list used to generate the combined results. It must contain exactly two elements.

    • combineLists

      private void combineLists(List<String> list1, List<String> list2)
      Combines each element of the first list with each element of the second list, and updates the first list with the combined results.

      This method takes two lists of strings, list1 and list2. It generates a new list where each string from list1 is concatenated with each string from list2, separated by a space. The original list1 is then cleared and replaced with this newly created combined list.

      Parameters:
      list1 - The first list to be updated with the combined results. This list is cleared and populated with the new combined list.
      list2 - The second list used to generate the combined results. Each element in list1 is combined with every element in list2.

    • generateCollideAmbiguities

      private List<String> generateCollideAmbiguities(String input)

    • countZeroes

      private int countZeroes(String str)
      Counts the number of occurrences of the character '0' in a given string.

      This method calculates the number of '0' characters in the input string by comparing the length of the original string with the length of the string after all '0' characters have been removed.

      Parameters:
      str - The input string in which to count occurrences of '0'.
      Returns:
      The number of occurrences of '0' in the input string.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if str is null.
